oai_dc:dc.dc:title: A FIELD EXPERIMENT ON GRAVITY WAVES: EFFECTS OF THE WAVE STEEPNESS AND EFFECTIVE WATER DEPTH ON THE WAVE PROFILE AND BREAKING LIMIT
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Spiliotopoulos, George
Katsardi, Vanessa
Fiamma, Vincenzo
Ruzzo, Carlo
Romolo, Alessandra
Arena, Felice
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This paper describes a series of field observations of large surface gravity waves, recorded at the Natural Ocean Engineering Laboratory (NOEL), Italy. The study involves a variety of sea states measured at a series of water depths, from deep to the shallowest limit of intermediate waters. The discussion is focused on the effect of the spectral and local wave parameters, described by the wave steepness and the effective water depth, on the wave profile, statistical properties and the breaking characteristics. The data presented show a transition in the dispersive properties of the wavefield as waves propagate from deep to shallower water. This is indicated both in the wave profiles as well as the wave height distributions. Leading roles, albeit competitive to each other, play the wave steepness and wave breaking.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Coastal Engineering Proceedings; No. 38 (2024): Proceedings of 38th Conference on Coastal Engineering, Rome, Italy, 2024; papers.12
